purpleculture_info:
(Simplified: 来)
Synonym: 沒有
Antonyms: 去 往
Ideographic: A wheat plant that has just borne fruit; compare 来
purpleculture_examples: 來到 [ lái dào ]: to come; to arrive
purpleculture_tree:
• ⿻ Overlaid
    • 木 [ mù ] tree; wood, lumber; wooden
    • 从 [ cóng ] from, by, since, whence, through
heisig_chinese_memo: The assembly line can be quite boring.  The wood keeps comeing in on the conveyor belt and the assembly line keeps processing it.
Ru_Notes: Традиционная форма одного из самых распространённых кандзи, 来 (くる、ライ приходить). Почти не используется.
Ru_Radicals: 一 (один), ｜, 人 (человек), ハ, 十 (десять), 木 (дерево)
Ru_trainchinese:
lái: (глаг/прил) приходить, происходить, наступать; получать, зарабатывать; будущий, следующий
lái: (глаг) (перед глаголом) показатель будущего времени; (после глагола) указывает на цель, результат или прогноз; указывает на движение по направлению к говорящему
lái: (глаг) используется для замены другого глагола (приносить, пить, петь и т.д.); используется для обозначения манеры или отношения
lái: (глаг) указывает на возможность или невозможность совершения действия (после 得 или 不)
lái: (графема) используется в балладах, чтобы заполнить слог
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: With one rice grain many more always come! People are often like this too.
origin_of_ch_char_book: (來, 来, lai, come) This character originally meant barley (麥, 麦, mai, wheat; barley). According to the ancient scripts, this character meant “to receive holy barley.” In other words, it meant that heaven (天, tian=t’ien) gave barley to humanity; the sacred barley came from heaven. Therefore the character came to mean “to come.”
humanum_full_description_en:
First, let's talk about the evolution of the word " lai " in terms of the font. The oracle bone inscription " Lai " is like wheat, which is the original word for wheat, and is generally thought to refer to wheat. In the middle of the glyph is a straight-up ear of wheat, with the leaves drooping on both sides, and the stem and root under the leaves. The upper end of the word may be drawn diagonally or horizontally. The wheat ears are straight up, because the wheat stalks are strong and the hollows are knotted like bamboo (see Luo Zhenyu, Zhang Zhe).

Many oracle bone inscriptions " Lai " have an oblique or horizontal drawing at the top. Some scholars believe that there should be no horizontal or oblique drawing at the beginning of the character. Later, an oblique or horizontal drawing was added to distinguish its original meaning (Mai Zizhi) and false meaning (communication). Come). However, there is no clear and consistent application of this distinction in actual Oracle examples (see Ji Xusheng). In other words, even if the word does not add a horizontal or diagonal drawing, it is useful to express the situation of the coming of wheat, and there are also examples of expressing the coming. In other words, the horizontal painting may be an imperceptible superfluous pen (see Qiu Xigui), or a decorative pen (see "An Analysis on the Genealogy of Ancient Chinese Characters"). Other scholars believe that horizontal painting represents wheat ears (such as Li Yu).

Inscriptions on the oracle bones are carried on by the inscriptions, some are pictograms of the whole wheat, and some add a horizontal painting on the top of the glyphs, but (mostly) they are not capped. The second type of glyph is more common.

The following is a brief explanation of the meaning of " come ".

With regard to the usage of Oracle, here are five points. 1. " Lai " in inscriptions is rarely used as the original meaning (that is, wheat). The only examples are: "Yihaibu, Shoulaihe. Two" ("Oracle Bone Inscriptions" 33260), of which "Shoulaihe" Come " should be pronounced " Mai ". It means "Bu Q: How about accepting (wheat)? Or is it going to be harvested?" That is to ask which crop will yield a good harvest (see Wen Shaofeng, Yuan Tingdong).

Second, there are many examples of " Lai " using its false meaning. It means that when going from somewhere to somewhere, some are used to come and go, and some are used to communicate. It is used as the meaning of "returning" and "returning also." A common example is "Changing and dying disaster" (press: " Death " means nothing), which means "going in and out of peace". Another example is "Fu Bu Qi Lai [See] Wang" ("Oracle Bone Inscriptions" 1027 Zheng). Or like "The Rain Comes From the West" ("Oracle Bone Inscriptions" 12872). In addition, the phrase "Wang Laizheng (Zheng) Renfang" is often used in oracle bone inscriptions, which means that Wang went to conquer people (" ren " is the name of Fang's country). Here " to " its dealings with the " go " meaning.

3. It is used to express the meaning of paying tribute, such as "Xi Lai Bai Ma" ("Oracle Bone Inscriptions" 9177 Zheng). Another example is "Lai Ma" and "Lai Niu" (see Li Xiaoding, Yao Xiaosui).

Fourth, it is used to mean the coming and future. For example, the term "coming new year" in the inscriptions means next year and coming year. In the inscriptions, the stems and branches within one ten days are called " now ", the stems and branches in the next ten days are called " yi ", and the stems and branches in the next ten days are called " lai " (see Yao Xiaosui). For the saying that " Yi " in the inscriptions means the near future and " come " means the far future, you can refer to Wu Qichang.

Fifth, it is used as a place name, such as "I have not yet known, it will not rain today, so I will come." ("Oracle Bone Inscriptions" 20907). " Lai " may be " Lai ". It was destroyed by Qi Ling in the Spring and Autumn Period. Laizi City, Huang County, Shandong. "Zuo Zhuan. "The Sixth Year of Xianggong": "Qihou defeated Lai."

In terms of the meanings of inscriptions, there are mainly three (refer to "General Explanation of Inscriptions in Inscriptions"). First, it is used for coming, such as the history wall plate: "The ancestor of Huishi Ci (lie) came to see King Wu." Secondly, it is used as a name, see the 鼄来鹹鬲: "鼄 (邾)邾隹 Zha (as) Zhen (ding)". The third is to be used for the coming year, such as Chu Ding: "Donggong Nai said: "Reward (repay) Changhe ten zi, left ten zi, for twenty zi, [if] next year Fu reward (pay), pay卌(forty) Zi." "The next year" means the coming year and next year.

As can be seen from the above use cases of the Jiajin inscriptions, " come " has the hypothesis to mean from there to here, from far to near, or from somewhere to somewhere. "Er Ya. "Explanation on the Interpretation": "Come, to the end." "Yu Pian. "Laibu": "Come, return." In addition, in Jiajin's use case, there is also the use of " lai " to indicate the future or the righteousness. This should be the application of the aforementioned meaning from far to near to describe or measure the distance of time way of doing. "Xunzi. Jiezhe: "Don't want to go, don't come to Min."

In addition, there is a variant of the word [laizhi] in Chu bamboo slips, where the upper part is always the lower part (see Liu Zhao), in which " stop " should be the meaning symbol. For example: "If the people of the people send one [Laizhi] at four o'clock, the people will be harmless" (Guodian Chujian. Yucong 4:21). Among them [来止] is obviously used to come and go.

"Shuowen" preached " come " and said: "The remembrance received in the week comes to the bar. One comes and two seams, like the shape of a mang prince. The heaven comes, so it comes from the walk. The "Poetry" says: "I Lai Lun." All those who come have never come. Luo Aiqi." Some people may think that Xu Shen's teaching about Lai Mai "Heaven is also inexplicable." Li Yu proposed a reference for this. According to some researches on human cultural history and archaeology, many myths and legends are often closely related to real history. In ancient China, there was a saying that wheat "heaven comes from", this phenomenon reflects a possibility: wheat is not native to China (press: the origin of wheat is in the fertile crescent of the Middle East, and Chinese wheat may have been imported from the Western Regions). The coming of wheat is used as the coming of the trip, because "the wheat seed comes from outside" (cf. Zhang Shunhui). This statement can be regarded as a reasonable supplement to Xu Shen's statement that "Heaven comes."
humanum_short_description_en: Oracle " Lai " is the first pictographic writing of the " Mai " of the wheat , which was later used as a reciprocal communication, and it was borrowed for a long time. It is said that " Lai " is borrowed to come and come, and the meaning symbol "夊" (shaped downward like the sole of the foot, see "夊") is added to clearly indicate its action. However, due to come to the word used for the writing of it, and save " additional information " (see Hong Jiayi). The original meaning of " mai " is used as the meaning of wheat.
humanum_full_description:
先就字形方面說「來」字的演變。甲骨文「來」象麥子，是麥子之麥的本字，一般以為指小麥。字形中間是直上的麥穗，兩邊葉子下垂，葉下是莖和根。其字上端或加斜或橫畫。麥穗直上，因為麥莖堅強，中空有節似竹（參羅振玉、張哲）。

　　不少甲骨文「來」字上端加斜或橫畫，有學者認為其字最初本應無橫或斜畫，後來增一斜或橫畫以辨其初義（麥子之來）與假借義（往來之來）。不過，在實際甲骨文文例中未見明確而一致的應用此區分（參季旭昇）。換言之，即或字無增一橫或斜畫，有用以表達麥子之來的情況，亦有表示到來之來的例子。或說橫畫可能是無深意的贅筆（參裘錫圭），或說是飾筆（參《古文字譜系疏證》）。另有學者認為横畫代表麥穗（如李裕）。

　　金文承甲骨文字形，有的作整株麥子之象形，有的在字形上端加一橫畫，但（多）不封頂。第二種字形較為常見。

　　以下就「來」的用義作簡單的說明。

　　在甲骨文的用法方面，於此提出五點。一，卜辭中「來」少見用作本義（即麥子）的例子，僅有的如︰「乙亥卜，受來禾。 二」（《甲骨文合集》33260），其中「受來禾」之「來」應讀作「麥」。意思是「卜問︰受來（麥）呢？還是受禾呢？」即卜問哪一種作物收成會好（參溫少峰，袁庭棟）。

　　二，「來」用其假借義的例子，卜辭多見。表示由某處至某處時，有的用為來去之來，有的用作來往之往。用作返也、還也之意，常見的例子如「往來亡災」（按︰「亡」即無也），意近「出入平安」。又如「缶不其來[見]王」（《甲骨文合集》1027正）。又或如「來雨自西」（《甲骨文合集》12872）。另外，甲骨文中常見「王來正（征）人方」一語，表示王往征伐人（「人」乃方國名）。此處「來」用其往來之「往」意。

　　三，用以表示來貢之意，如「奚來白馬」（《甲骨文合集》9177正）。又如「來馬」、「來牛」之類（參李孝定、姚孝遂）。

　　四，用為將至、將來之義，如卜辭中「來歲」一語即明年、來年之意。卜辭於一旬內之干支稱「今」，下一旬之干支稱「翌」，再下一旬之干支稱「來」（參姚孝遂）。對於卜辭中「翌」表示較近的將來而「來」表示較遠的將來之說，可參吳其昌。

　　五，用作地名，如「己未卜，今日不雨，才（在）來。」（《甲骨文合集》20907）其中「來」可能是「萊」，春秋時被齊靈公所滅，地處今山東黃縣萊子城。《左傳．襄公六年》︰「齊侯滅萊。」

　　金文用義方面，主要有三（參《金文形義通解》）。其一，用作到來之來，如史牆盤︰「徽史刺（烈）祖廼來見武王」。其二，用為名字，見鼄來隹鬲︰「鼄（邾）來隹乍（作）貞（鼎）」。其三，用作來年之來，如曶鼎︰「東宮廼曰︰『賞（償）曶禾十秭，遺十秭，為廿秭，[若]來歲弗賞（償），則付卌（四十）秭。』」「來歲」即來年、明年。

　　從以上甲金文的用例可見，「來」皆有假借表示由彼至此、由遠到近，或從某處至某處。《爾雅．釋詁上》︰「來，至也。」《玉篇．來部》︰「來，歸也。」另外，甲金用例中，亦有借「來」表示將來或將至義，這該是把前述由遠至近之義應用於描述或衡量時日之遠近的做法。《荀子．解蔽》︰「不慕往，不閔來。」

　　另外，楚簡中有來字異體[來止]，上從來下從止（參劉釗），其中「止」應是義符。例如︰「其民者，若四時一遣一[來止]，而民弗害也」（郭店楚簡．語叢四．21）。其中[來止]明顯用作來去之來。

　　《說文》訓「來」曰︰「周所受瑞麥來麰。一來二縫，象芒朿之形。天所來也，故爲行來之來。《詩》曰：『詒我來麰。』凡來之屬皆从來。洛哀切。」對於許慎關於來麥「天所來也」一訓，有人或許認為是莫名其妙，對此李裕提出了一個可供參考的說法。根據一些人類文化歷史及考古學的研究，許多神話與傳說，往往與真實的歷史密切關連。中國古有麥子「天所來也」之說，此現象反映一種可能︰麥子非中國土產（按︰小麥的原產地在中東的新月沃土，中國的小麥可能自西域傳入）。小麥之來用作行來之來，是由於「麥種得自外來」（參張舜徽）。這個說法可算是對許慎所言「天所來也」的一個合理補正。
humanum_short_description: 甲骨文「來」是麥子之「麥」的象形初文，後假借為來往之來，久借不還。一說「來」被借用作去來之來，並加注義符「夊」（象腳掌向下形，參見「夊」）以明示其行動義。然而，由於來去之來字常用，為刻寫之便，又省掉「夊」（參洪家義）。而「麥」字原本的來往之來義，卻用作麥子之麥義。

HSK 1: 來,来
origin_of_ch_char_book: (來, 来, lai, come) This character originally meant barley (麥, 麦, mai, wheat; barley). According to the ancient scripts, this character meant “to receive holy barley.” In other words, it meant that heaven (天, tian=t’ien) gave barley to humanity; the sacred barley came from heaven. Therefore the character came to mean “to come.”
來來RS come, coming, return, returning
  • people 人人 hanging in a tree 木: after a while they come crashing down and return to the ground
 al. 来

来来RS 來 come, coming, return, returning
  • modf. 來 → 来
 夹; 参; 因 致 醸
(Simplified: 来)
Chinese Definition: Synonym: 沒有
Antonyms: 去 往
Ideographic: A wheat plant that has just borne fruit; compare 来
  • ⿻ Overlaid
    • 木 [ mù ] tree; wood, lumber; wooden
    • 从 [ cóng ] from, by, since, whence, through
①由另一方面到這一方面，與“往”、“去”相對：來回。來往。過來。歸來。來鴻去燕(喻來回遷徙，不能在一地常住；亦喻書信來往)。
②從過去到現在：從來。向來。
③現在以後，未到的時間：來年。將來。來日方長。
④用在數詞或數量詞後面，表示約略估計：二百來頭豬。
⑤做某個動作：胡來。
⑥用在動詞前，表示要做某事：大家來動腦筋。
⑦用在動詞後，表示做過(一般均可用“來着”)：昨天他哭來。
⑧用在動詞後，表示動作的趨向：上來。
⑨表示發生：暴風雨來了。
⑩在數詞一、二、三後面，表示列舉理由：這臺收錄機一來音質好，二來價錢便宜，我就買了。
⑾用做詩、歌詞中的襯字：八月裏來桂花香。
⑿表示語氣，歸去來兮！
⒀姓氏。

Story: With one rice grain many more always come! People are often like this too.
Kind: traditional

先就字形方面說「 來 」字的演變。甲骨文「 來 」象麥子，是麥子之麥的本字，一般以為指小麥。字形中間是直上的麥穗，兩邊葉子下垂，葉下是莖和根。其字上端或加斜或橫畫。麥穗直上，因為麥莖堅強，中空有節似竹（參羅振玉、張哲）。 不少甲骨文「 來 」字上端加斜或橫畫，有學者認為其字最初本應無橫或斜畫，後來增一斜或橫畫以辨其初義（麥子之來）與假借義（往來之來）。不過，在實際甲骨文文例中未見明確而一致的應用此區分（參季旭昇）。換言之，即或字無增一橫或斜畫，有用以表達麥子之來的情況，亦有表示到來之來的例子。或說橫畫可能是無深意的贅筆（參裘錫圭），或說是飾筆（參《古文字譜系疏證》）。另有學者認為横畫代表麥穗（如李裕）。 金文承甲骨文字形，有的作整株麥子之象形，有的在字形上端加一橫畫，但（多）不封頂。第二種字形較為常見。 以下就「 來 」的用義作簡單的說明。 在甲骨文的用法方面，於此提出五點。一，卜辭中「 來 」少見用作本義（即麥子）的例子，僅有的如︰「乙亥卜，受來禾。 二」（《甲骨文合集》33260），其中「受來禾」之「 來 」應讀作「 麥 」。意思是「卜問︰受來（麥）呢？還是受禾呢？」即卜問哪一種作物收成會好（參溫少峰，袁庭棟）。 二，「 來 」用其假借義的例子，卜辭多見。表示由某處至某處時，有的用為來去之來，有的用作來往之往。用作返也、還也之意，常見的例子如「往來亡災」（按︰「 亡 」即無也），意近「出入平安」。又如「缶不其來[見]王」（《甲骨文合集》1027正）。又或如「來雨自西」（《甲骨文合集》12872）。另外，甲骨文中常見「王來正（征）人方」一語，表示王往征伐人（「 人 」乃方國名）。此處「 來 」用其往來之「 往 」意。 三，用以表示來貢之意，如「奚來白馬」（《甲骨文合集》9177正）。又如「來馬」、「來牛」之類（參李孝定、姚孝遂）。 四，用為將至、將來之義，如卜辭中「來歲」一語即明年、來年之意。卜辭於一旬內之干支稱「 今 」，下一旬之干支稱「 翌 」，再下一旬之干支稱「 來 」（參姚孝遂）。對於卜辭中「 翌 」表示較近的將來而「 來 」表示較遠的將來之說，可參吳其昌。 五，用作地名，如「己未卜，今日不雨，才（在）來。」（《甲骨文合集》20907）其中「 來 」可能是「 萊 」，春秋時被齊靈公所滅，地處今山東黃縣萊子城。《左傳．襄公六年》︰「齊侯滅萊。」 金文用義方面，主要有三（參《金文形義通解》）。其一，用作到來之來，如史牆盤︰「徽史刺（烈）祖廼來見武王」。其二，用為名字，見鼄來隹鬲︰「鼄（邾）來隹乍（作）貞（鼎）」。其三，用作來年之來，如曶鼎︰「東宮廼曰︰『賞（償）曶禾十秭，遺十秭，為廿秭，[若]來歲弗賞（償），則付卌（四十）秭。』」「來歲」即來年、明年。 從以上甲金文的用例可見，「 來 」皆有假借表示由彼至此、由遠到近，或從某處至某處。《爾雅．釋詁上》︰「來，至也。」《玉篇．來部》︰「來，歸也。」另外，甲金用例中，亦有借「 來 」表示將來或將至義，這該是把前述由遠至近之義應用於描述或衡量時日之遠近的做法。《荀子．解蔽》︰「不慕往，不閔來。」 另外，楚簡中有來字異體[來止]，上從來下從止（參劉釗），其中「 止 」應是義符。例如︰「其民者，若四時一遣一[來止]，而民弗害也」（郭店楚簡．語叢四．21）。其中[來止]明顯用作來去之來。 《說文》訓「 來 」曰︰「周所受瑞麥來麰。一來二縫，象芒朿之形。天所來也，故爲行來之來。《詩》曰：『詒我來麰。』凡來之屬皆从來。洛哀切。」對於許慎關於來麥「天所來也」一訓，有人或許認為是莫名其妙，對此李裕提出了一個可供參考的說法。根據一些人類文化歷史及考古學的研究，許多神話與傳說，往往與真實的歷史密切關連。中國古有麥子「天所來也」之說，此現象反映一種可能︰麥子非中國土產（按︰小麥的原產地在中東的新月沃土，中國的小麥可能自西域傳入）。小麥之來用作行來之來，是由於「麥種得自外來」（參張舜徽）。這個說法可算是對許慎所言「天所來也」的一個合理補正。
First, let's talk about the evolution of the word " lai" in terms of the font. The oracle bone inscription " Lai" is like wheat, which is the original word for wheat, and is generally thought to refer to wheat. In the middle of the glyph is a straight-up ear of wheat, with the leaves drooping on both sides, and the stem and root under the leaves. The upper end of the word may be drawn diagonally or horizontally. The wheat ears are straight up, because the wheat stalks are strong and the hollows are knotted like bamboo (see Luo Zhenyu, Zhang Zhe). Many oracle bone inscriptions " Lai" have an oblique or horizontal drawing at the top. Some scholars believe that there should be no horizontal or oblique drawing at the beginning of the character. Later, an oblique or horizontal drawing was added to distinguish its original meaning (Mai Zizhi) and false meaning (communication). Come). However, there is no clear and consistent application of this distinction in actual Oracle examples (see Ji Xusheng). In other words, even if the word does not add a horizontal or diagonal drawing, it is useful to express the situation of the coming of wheat, and there are also examples of expressing the coming. In other words, the horizontal painting may be an imperceptible superfluous pen (see Qiu Xigui), or a decorative pen (see "An Analysis on the Genealogy of Ancient Chinese Characters"). Other scholars believe that horizontal painting represents wheat ears (such as Li Yu). Inscriptions on the oracle bones are carried on by the inscriptions, some are pictograms of the whole wheat, and some add a horizontal painting on the top of the glyphs, but (mostly) they are not capped. The second type of glyph is more common. The following is a brief explanation of the meaning of " come". With regard to the usage of Oracle, here are five points. 1. " Lai" in inscriptions is rarely used as the original meaning (that is, wheat). The only examples are: "Yihaibu, Shoulaihe. Two" ("Oracle Bone Inscriptions" 33260), of which "Shoulaihe" Come" should be pronounced " Mai". It means "Bu Q: How about accepting (wheat)? Or is it going to be harvested?" That is to ask which crop will yield a good harvest (see Wen Shaofeng, Yuan Tingdong). Second, there are many examples of " Lai" using its false meaning. It means that when going from somewhere to somewhere, some are used to come and go, and some are used to communicate. It is used as the meaning of "returning" and "returning also." A common example is "Changing and dying disaster" (press: " Death" means nothing), which means "going in and out of peace". Another example is "Fu Bu Qi Lai [See] Wang" ("Oracle Bone Inscriptions" 1027 Zheng). Or like "The Rain Comes From the West" ("Oracle Bone Inscriptions" 12872). In addition, the phrase "Wang Laizheng (Zheng) Renfang" is often used in oracle bone inscriptions, which means that Wang went to conquer people (" ren" is the name of Fang's country). Here " to" its dealings with the " go" meaning. 3. It is used to express the meaning of paying tribute, such as "Xi Lai Bai Ma" ("Oracle Bone Inscriptions" 9177 Zheng). Another example is "Lai Ma" and "Lai Niu" (see Li Xiaoding, Yao Xiaosui). Fourth, it is used to mean the coming and future. For example, the term "coming new year" in the inscriptions means next year and coming year. In the inscriptions, the stems and branches within one ten days are called " now", the stems and branches in the next ten days are called " yi", and the stems and branches in the next ten days are called " lai" (see Yao Xiaosui). For the saying that " Yi" in the inscriptions means the near future and " come" means the far future, you can refer to Wu Qichang. Fifth, it is used as a place name, such as "I have not yet known, it will not rain today, so I will come." ("Oracle Bone Inscriptions" 20907). " Lai" may be " Lai". It was destroyed by Qi Ling in the Spring and Autumn Period. Laizi City, Huang County, Shandong. "Zuo Zhuan. "The Sixth Year of Xianggong": "Qihou defeated Lai." In terms of the meanings of inscriptions, there are mainly three (refer to "General Explanation of Inscriptions in Inscriptions"). First, it is used for coming, such as the history wall plate: "The ancestor of Huishi Ci (lie) came to see King Wu." Secondly, it is used as a name, see the 鼄来鹹鬲: "鼄 (邾)邾隹 Zha (as) Zhen (ding)". The third is to be used for the coming year, such as Chu Ding: "Donggong Nai said: "Reward (repay) Changhe ten zi, left ten zi, for twenty zi, [if] next year Fu reward (pay), pay卌(forty) Zi." "The next year" means the coming year and next year. As can be seen from the above use cases of the Jiajin inscriptions, " come" has the hypothesis to mean from there to here, from far to near, or from somewhere to somewhere. "Er Ya. "Explanation on the Interpretation": "Come, to the end." "Yu Pian. "Laibu": "Come, return." In addition, in Jiajin's use case, there is also the use of " lai" to indicate the future or the righteousness. This should be the application of the aforementioned meaning from far to near to describe or measure the distance of time way of doing. "Xunzi. Jiezhe: "Don't want to go, don't come to Min." In addition, there is a variant of the word [laizhi] in Chu bamboo slips, where the upper part is always the lower part (see Liu Zhao), in which " stop" should be the meaning symbol. For example: "If the people of the people send one [Laizhi] at four o'clock, the people will be harmless" (Guodian Chujian. Yucong 4:21). Among them [来止] is obviously used to come and go. "Shuowen" preached " come" and said: "The remembrance received in the week comes to the bar. One comes and two seams, like the shape of a mang prince. The heaven comes, so it comes from the walk. The "Poetry" says: "I Lai Lun." All those who come have never come. Luo Aiqi." Some people may think that Xu Shen's teaching about Lai Mai "Heaven is also inexplicable." Li Yu proposed a reference for this. According to some researches on human cultural history and archaeology, many myths and legends are often closely related to real history. In ancient China, there was a saying that wheat "heaven comes from", this phenomenon reflects a possibility: wheat is not native to China (press: the origin of wheat is in the fertile crescent of the Middle East, and Chinese wheat may have been imported from the Western Regions). The coming of wheat is used as the coming of the trip, because "the wheat seed comes from outside" (cf. Zhang Shunhui). This statement can be regarded as a reasonable supplement to Xu Shen's statement that "Heaven comes."

來字的基本解释

來
lái
见“来”。

來字的汉语字典释义

[①]［lái］
［《廣韻》落哀切，平咍，來。］
“倈1”的今字。“来1”的繁体字。
(1)小麦。
(2)引申泛指五谷之穗。
(3)由彼及此；由远到近。与“去”、“往”相对。
(4)回来，返回。
(5)特指已嫁女子回娘家省亲。
(6)归服；归顺。
(7)后多作“徠”。招致；招揽。
(8)产生；开始；发生。
(9)未来，将来。
(10)指次于今年、今天的。参见“來年”、“來早”。
(11)往昔，过去。
(12)以来，表示时间从过去某时持续到现在。
(13)指来孙。
(14)犹言一样、一般。表示比况。
(15)由来。从发生到现在。
(16)由来。事物发生的原因。
(17)表示做某个动作。
(18)用在动词或动词结构前面，表示要做某事。
(19)用在另一动词或动词结构后面，表示来到某处做某事。
(20)用在两个动词或动词结构中间，表示前者是方法、态度，后者是目的。
(21)用在动词后面，表示动作的趋向。
(22)用在动词后面，表示动作的结果。

來字的康熙字典解释

【子集中】【人字部】　來； 康熙笔画：8； 页码：页101第16
〔古文〕徠【廣韻】落哀切【集韻】【韻會】【正韻】郞才切，?賴平聲。至也，還也，及也。【禮·曲禮】禮尚往來。往而不來，非禮也。來而不往，亦非禮也。　又【公羊傳·隱五年】公觀魚於棠，登來之也。【註】登讀爲得，齊人謂求得爲登來。　又玄孫之子曰來孫。　又麥名。【詩·周頌】貽我來牟。【前漢·劉向傳】作飴我釐麰。亦作䅘。　又呼也。【周禮·春官】大祝來瞽令臯舞。　又姓。　又【集韻】洛代切，音賚。撫其至日來。【孟子】放勳曰：勞之來之。　又叶鄰奚切，音離。【詩·邶風】莫往莫來，悠悠我思。【素問】恬澹虛無，眞氣從之。精神守內，病安從來。　又叶郞狄切，音力。【詩·小雅】東人之子，職勞不來。叶下服。【大雅】經始勿亟，庶民子來。　又叶落蓋切，音賴。【屈原·離騷】因氣變而遂會舉兮，忽神奔而鬼怪。時髣髴以遙見兮，精皎皎以往來。　又叶良置切，音利。【荀子·賦篇】一往一來，結尾以爲事。

考證：〔【荀子·賦論篇】一往一來，結尾以爲事。〕　謹照原書省

Come
Basic explanation of words
Come
lái

Come
Chinese dictionary definition of words
[①]［lái］
["Guangyun" fell mourning and cut, flat 咍, come. ]
The present character of "倈1". "来1" in traditional characters.
(1) Wheat.
(2) By extension, it refers to the ears of five grains.
(3) From there to this; from far to near. Contrast with "to" and "toward".
(4) Come back, return.
(5) Especially referring to married women who return to their natal families to give birth to them.
(6) Submit; submit.
(7) Later, "Lei" is often used. To incur; to solicit.
(8) Produce; begin; happen.
(9) The future, the future.
(10) Refers to next to this year and today. See "coming year", "coming early".
(11) The past, the past.
(12) Since, it means that time has lasted from some time in the past to the present.
(13) Refers to the coming grandson.
(14) It's still the same and ordinary. Represents the situation.
(15) Origin. From happening to now.
(16) Origin. The reason why things happen.
(17) means to do a certain action.
(18) Used in front of a verb or verb structure to indicate to do something.
(19) Used after another verb or verb structure to mean to come somewhere to do something.
(20) Used in the middle of two verbs or verb structures, it means that the former is method and attitude, and the latter is purpose.
(21) Used after a verb to indicate the tendency of an action.
(22) Used after a verb to indicate the result of an action.
Come
